facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 638 of 1952 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated May 21, 1957 of the Assam High Court in First Appeal No. 7 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 638 of 1952. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated May 21, 1957 of the Assam High Court in First Appeal No. 7, of 1962.

facts.text: Appellants carry on business at Raha in Nowgong District.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants carrying on business at Raha in Nowgong District had dealings with the respondents, carrying on business at Gauhati.

facts.text: Respondents carry on business at Gauhati.

anchor.surface_text: carrying on business at Gauhati. As a result of the said dealings, the appellants were indebted to the respondents in a sum of Rs. 9,447-4-9.

facts.text: Appellants were indebted to respondents in a sum of Rs. 9,447-4-9.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the said dealings, the appellants were indebted to the respondents in a sum of Rs. 9,447-4-9. In order to satisfy the dues of the respondents, the appellants sent to the respondents a cheque for Rs. 9,461-4-0 dated August 31, 1948.

facts.text: Appellants sent to respondents a cheque for Rs. 9,461-4-0 dated August 31, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: In order to satisfy the dues of the respondents, the appellants sent to the respondents a cheque for Rs. 9,461-4-0 dated August 31, 1948. The cheque was drawn by a third party, Messrs. Nathuram Jaidayal of Sibsagar on the Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar Branch, in favour of the appellants, who endorsed it to the respondents.

facts.text: Cheque was drawn by Messrs. Nathuram Jaidayal of Sibsagar on Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar Branch, in favour of appellants, endorsed by appellants to respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The cheque was drawn by a third party, Messrs. Nathuram Jaidayal of Sibsagar on the Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar Branch, in favour of the appellants, who endorsed it to the respondents. On September 4, 1948, the respondents sent the cheque to their bankers, the Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati for companylection.

facts.text: On September 4, 1948, respondents sent the cheque to Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati for collection.

anchor.surface_text: On September 4, 1948, the respondents sent the cheque to their bankers, the Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati for companylection. On the same day, the Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati sent the cheque to the Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar for encashment.

facts.text: On September 4, 1948, Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati sent the cheque to Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar for encashment.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day, the Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati sent the cheque to the Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar for encashment. The Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar debited the accounts of their companystituents. Messrs Nahuram Jaidayal with the sum of Rs. 9,461-4-0, and after deducting Rs. 6-4-0 on account of companymission charges, sent to the Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati a draft for Rs. 9,435/-dated September 14, 1948 towards payment of the cheque.

facts.text: Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar debited accounts of Messrs Nathuram Jaidayal with Rs. 9,461-4-0.

anchor.surface_text: The Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar debited the accounts of their companystituents. Messrs Nahuram Jaidayal with the sum of Rs. 9,461-4-0, and after deducting Rs. 6-4-0 on account of companymission charges, sent to the Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati a draft for Rs. 9,435/-dated September 14, 1948 towards payment of the cheque.

facts.text: Tripura Modern Bank deducted Rs. 6-4-0 commission and sent draft for Rs. 9,435 dated September 14, 1948 to Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati.

anchor.surface_text: and after deducting Rs. 6-4-0 on account of companymission charges, sent to the Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati a draft for Rs. 9,435/-dated September 14, 1948 towards payment of the cheque. The draft was drawn by the Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar on its Calcutta Head Office, and was marked current for three months from the date of the issue.

facts.text: Draft drawn by Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar on Calcutta Head Office, current for three months.

anchor.surface_text: The draft was drawn by the Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar on its Calcutta Head Office, and was marked current for three months from the date of the issue. On receipt of the draft, the Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati sent it to their Head Office at Calcutta for companylection.

facts.text: Calcutta Commercial Bank never presented the draft to Tripura Modern Bank and made no attempts to collect.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of the draft, the Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati sent it to their Head Office at Calcutta for companylection. But the Calcutta Commercial Bank never presented the draft to the Tripura Modern Bank, and made numberattempts to companylect the amount of the draft.

facts.text: On September 17, 1948, Calcutta Commercial Bank closed its business and was ordered to be wound up.

anchor.surface_text: On September 17, 1948, the Calcutta Commercial Bank closed its business, and subsequently, it was ordered to be wound up. On October 16, 1948, the Tripura Modern Bank also closed its business.

facts.text: On October 16, 1948, Tripura Modern Bank closed its business and entered into a scheme of arrangement with creditors.

anchor.surface_text: On October 16, 1948, the Tripura Modern Bank also closed its business. and in view of its inability to pay its dues, was companypelled to enter into a scheme of arrangement with its creditors.

facts.text: On November 19, 1948, respondents requested Tripura Modern Bank to pay amount of draft to them not to Calcutta Commercial Bank.

anchor.surface_text: On November 19, 1948, the respondents requested the Tripura Modern Bank to pay the amount of the draft to them and number 10 the Calcutta Commercial Bank. But numberpayment was made by the Tripura Modern Bank either to the respondents or to the Calcutta Commercial Bank.

facts.text: No payment made by Tripura Modern Bank to respondents or Calcutta Commercial Bank.

anchor.surface_text: But numberpayment was made by the Tripura Modern Bank either to the respondents or to the Calcutta Commercial Bank. On March 8, 1949, the respondents instituted the suit, out of which the appeal arises, claiming payment of their dues from the appellants on the footing that the cheque dated August 31, 1948 was received by the respondents as a companyditional payment,

facts.text: On March 8, 1949, respondents instituted the suit claiming payment from appellants as cheque was conditional payment and not cashed.

anchor.surface_text: On March 8, 1949, the respondents instituted the suit, out of which the appeal arises, claiming payment of their dues from the appellants on the footing that the cheque dated August 31, 1948 was received by the respondents as a companyditional payment, and as the cheque was number cashed, the respondents were entitled to enforce their original claim.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge, Lower Assam District, dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge, Lower Assam District, dismissed the suit. On appeal, the High Court reversed the judgment appealed from, and decreed the suit.

facts.text: Assam High Court reversed Subordinate Judge's judgment and decreed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the High Court reversed the judgment appealed from, and decreed the suit. The appellants number appeal to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: P.W. 3 testified that draft sent by registered post to head office, returned undelivered as head office closed.

anchor.surface_text: P.W. 3, an employee of the Calcutta Commercial Bank, said that the draft, was sent by the Gauhati Office of the Bank to its head office by registered post, but the head office had closed its business and the draft came back to the Gauhati office undelivered.

facts.text: P.W. 3 admitted that if draft presented before October 16, 1948, it would have been paid.

anchor.surface_text: P.W. 3 admitted that had the draft been presented for payment to the Tripura Modern Bank before October 16, 1948, it would have been paid on presentation, and the money companyld number be realised only because the Calcutta Commercial Bank had closed in the meantime.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court judgment, restored trial court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: In the result. the appeal is allowed, the judgment and decree passed by the High Court are set aside, and those of the trial Court are restored.

facts.text: On November 19, 1948, respondents wrote to Tripura Modern Bank Calcutta agent claiming draft belonged to them, not CCB, request direct payment.

anchor.surface_text: After the respondents Bank went into liquidation the respondents wrote a letter on November 19, 1948 to the Agent of the Tripura Modern Bank Ltd., Calcutta saying that the demand draft belonged to them and number to the Calcutta Commercial Bank Ltd., who were only acting as their agents for companylection purposes and that the amount for which the draft was drawn should be paid to them and number to the Calcutta Commercial Bank or any one on its behalf.

facts.text: Appellant wrote letter dated September 10, 1949 to respondents saying get cheque back.

anchor.surface_text: Reliance, however, was placed by Mr. S.C. Nath for the respondents upon the letter dated September 10, 1949 written by the appellant to the respondents in which the appellant wrote as follows. and received your letter. You wrote that the payment of Rs. 9,461-4-0 had number been received. Please get the cheque back.
Appeal by special leave

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee also contended that the respondents collecting agents must be deemed to have accepted the demand draft on September 14, 1948 as absolute payment of the cheque, and that the cheque was, in the eye of law, paid and discharged on that date. There is a lengthy discussion on this point in the judgment of the High Court, but we do not think it necessary to decide this, question.

arguments.claim: Where negotiable instrument accepted as conditional payment, creditor bound to present cheque within reasonable time; failure with prejudice makes it absolute payment (Chitty on Contracts Art. 1079).

anchor.surface_text: In Chitty on Contracts, 22nd Edn., Art. 1079, the law is stated thus Where a negotiable instrument, upon which the debtor is not primarily liable, is accepted by the creditor as conditional payment, he is bound to do all that a holder of such an instrument may do in order to get payment thus it is his duty to present a cheque within a reasonable time, and if he fails to do. so, and the debtor is thereby prejudiced, the creditor is guilty of laches and makes the cheque his own, so that it amounts to payment of the debt.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ed by the respondents as a companyditional payment, and as the cheque was number cashed, the respondents were entitled to enforce their original claim

arguments.claim: Creditor accepting order on banker who becomes insolvent due to laches discharged debtor (Addison on Contracts).

anchor.surface_text: In Addisons Treatise on the Law of Contracts, 11th Edn., p. 156, it is stated-- If the debtor makes an order upon his banker for payment of the amount of the debt, and the creditor accepts it, and keeps it in his hands an unreasonable time before presenting it for payment, and the banker becomes insolvent, the debtor is discharged on account of the laches of the creditor.

arguments.claim: Creditor taking cheque from debtor's agent bound to present within reasonable time; delay discharging debtor (Hopkins v. Ware).

anchor.surface_text: In Hobkins v. Ware 1 , it was held that a creditor who takes from his debtors agent on account of the debt the cheque of the agent, is bound to present it for payment within a reasonable time and if he fails to do so and by his delay alters for the worse the position of the debtor, the debtor is discharged, although he was not a party to the cheque.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: o the appellants, the respondents must be deemed to have retained the draft as absolute payment of the cheque, and on the payment of the cheque, the o

arguments.claim: Creditor holding bill/draft unreasonable time before demand, drawer insolvent: creditor's loss (Chamberlain v. Delarive).

anchor.surface_text: In the old case of Chamblerlyn v. Delarive 2  it was held that if a creditor accepting a bill or draft of his debtor upon a third person holds it an unreasonable time before he demands the money, and the person upon whom it is drawn becomes insolvent, it is the creditors own loss, though the draft be not a bill of exchange or negotiable.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: he cheque, and on the payment of the cheque, the original debt stood discharged. In Chitty on Contracts, 22nd Edn., Art. 1079, the law is stated thus

arguments.claim: High Court erred: failure to cash not due to laches; Tripura Bank stopped Sept 16 (wrong fact); no prejudice to appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was on error in holding that the failure to obtain payment of the draft was not due to the laches of the respondents collecting agents. In one part of the judgment, the High Court wrongly assumed. contrary to fact, that the Tripura Modern Bank had stopped business on September 16, 1948 and therefore the draft could not be cashed on presentation, whereas, in fact, the Tripura Modern Bank had stopped business a month later on October 16, 1948. Moreover, the High Court wrongly assumed that the appellants did not suffer any loss on account of the delay in the presentation of the draft.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Creditor bound to present negotiable instrument received as conditional payment within reasonable time; failure causing prejudice to debtor converts to absolute payment discharging debt, per Chitty Art. 1079, Addison, Hopkins v. Ware (1869), Chamberlain v. Delarive; applied to facts of delay post-Sept 14 until after Oct 16 bank closure confirmed by P.W. 3.

Their rights thereafter would rest only upon the demand draft and not upon the original debt

anchor.surface_text: After the respondents Bank went into liquidation the respondents wrote a letter on November 19, 1948 to the Agent of the Tripura Modern Bank Ltd., Calcutta saying that the demand draft belonged to them and not to the Calcutta Commercial Bank Ltd., who were only acting as their agents for collection purposes and that the amount for which the draft was drawn should be paid to them and not to the Calcutta Commercial Bank or any one on its behalf.
